data.title: Rio Tinto divests 61% stake in France's Alcan Engineered Products
data.meta_description: Anglo-Australian mining major Rio Tinto said Tuesday it has completed the divestment of a 61% stake in its French aluminium unit Alcan Engineered Products to funds linked to Apollo Global Management and Fonds Strategique d Investissement.
data.text:
Anglo-Australian mining major Rio Tinto said Tuesday it has completed thedivestment of a 61% stake in its French aluminium unit Alcan EngineeredProducts to funds linked to Apollo Global Management and Fonds Strategiqued'Investissement.

US private equity company Apollo is now the majority shareholder in AEP.

It holds a 51% stake in a new holding company for AEP, with France's FSIhaving 10%. Rio Tinto owns 39% of the company.

The terms of the deal are confidential, Rio Tinto said. "The closing of our majority divestment in AEP marks Rio Tinto's exit ofsubstantially all downstream businesses. Since 2008, we have completeddivestments in excess of US$11 billion," Guy Elliott, chief financial officerof Rio Tinto, said in a statement.

The mining company divested the composites division of the EngineeredProducts business in 2009.

In 2010, it completed divestments of $4.2 billion comprising AlcanPackaging Food Americas, Alcan Packaging global Pharmaceuticals, globalTobacco, Food Europe and Food Asia divisions, Vickery (Coal & Allied), MaulesCreek (Coal & Allied), Alcan Beauty Packaging, Alcan Medical Flexibles andCloud Peak Energy. The group maintains its ownership of Alcan Cable.

With the new ownership structure in place, AEP will undergo changes toits name and identity, Christel Bories, president and CEO of AEP, said inSeptember last year.

AEP produces aluminum products for the aerospace, mass transportation,automotive, packaging, energy and building industries. The packaging industryis responsible for around 31% of AEP's sales.

--Agnieszka Troszkiewicz, a_troszkiewicz@platts.com
